service_description:

Free telephone, email, online and in-person group support and resources to women and their families experiencing any variety of perinatal and postnatal mood disorders.

Blanchet House’s residential program is a 7-9 month work opportunity for men who are looking for a safe and sober environment while they establish a new direction in their lives. The program focuses on personal accountability and peer support as men help each other to build toward a healthier, more stable life. Phone interview with a Case Manager required for an assessment for appropriate fit in the program will be determined. Other requirements include drug testing, background check for sexual and/or violent offenses, and a 3-7 day work trial.

service_description:

therapy and peer mentors.

Facilities remain open but with modified services. Signs have been posted outside
our buildings instructing anyone who is sick to not enter the facility.

Daily screening of all persons who enter the building.
Detox is admitting patients 7 days a week on a walk-in only basis.
Residential programs are admitting patients. All admits will be screened for
symptoms.
Current patients are evaluated for illness and patients exhibiting symptoms will be
placed on mandatory isolated bed rest.
Visitations have been canceled at Adult Residential until further notice.
Visitations are limited at Youth Residential.
On-site 12-step meetings have been canceled until further notice.

Outpatient enrollment and services are available by telephone.
All outpatient groups will be offered by telephone.
Call 503-535-1151 to schedule appointments.
Patient relations staff will notify patients of cancellations or modifications to
programming by 9 a.m.
Peer mentor individual services will continue as scheduled.
Outings will be evaluated based on closures and location.
Treatment Readiness Groups are canceled until further notice.

Eligibility: Patients must have a true dental emergency and display no risk factors for COVID-19 (or have been exposed to someone with COVID-19).

A dental emergency/urgent care as defined by the American Dental Association is potentially life threatening and requires immediate treatment to stop ongoing tissue bleeding, relieve severe pain and/or risk of infection and to alleviate the burden on hospital emergency departments.

If the patient has any COVID-19 Symptoms as defined by the CDC they will not be
treated on the mobile clinic. We will screen for these symptoms curbside as well.
We seek to serve those without private insurance, who are low income and
vulnerable populations, but we will not turn away a patient with emergency needs with
no alternative options for care.

David Douglas School District will continue to provide breakfast and lunch pickups next
week from 9-11 a.m. at David Douglas High School South Building, Ron Russell Middle
School, Ventura Park Elementary and Gilbert Heights Elementary.
David Douglas School District will provide families with a (1) Chromebook if they do
not have a home computer/laptop/tablet and plan to distribute these during the week of
April 6. The current plan is to distribute Chromebooks to families at our 4 Grab-and-Go
food sites. We created a Family Chromebook Request Google form for you to fill out if
you need a Chromebook: https://www.ddouglas.k12.or.us/2020/03/family-resources-
during-the-coronavirus-shutdown/ .
During the closure, Multnomah County will keep only the Parkrose Student Based Health
Center open. Beginning on March 23, it will continue to offer in-person visits for certain
conditions when necessary after the concern is evaluated over the phone. Telemedicine
appointments will also be available. Please call 503-988-3392 for more information about
appointments at Parkrose Student Health Center. Student Health Centers are open to all
Multnomah County students ages 5-18. Please call prior to coming into a center so that
they are able to assist you as best they can. You will need to call and make an
appointment.

service_description:
The Providence Adult Outpatient Substance Use Treatment Program offers intensive outpatient and outpatient treatment services for adults with substance use disorders. We offer evidence-based treatment that encourages patients to take responsibility for their health and empowers them to develop their own solutions to the problems or challenges related to their use of alcohol and other substances. Our program serves adults whose drug or alcohol use is negatively impacting their lives. Includes Individual counseling, Group counseling sessions, including groups specific to men, women, families, and those experiencing mental health concerns, Training around coping skills, relapse prevention, mindfulness and interpersonal effectiveness 
Urine drug screenings, Oregon and Washington State licensed driver diversion/DUII and DWI prosecution programs, including treatment, court and state ordered drug screenings and educational services. Our program is patient-centered and uses Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) and motivational interviewing
Finding and Sustaining Recovery (FSR) is an integrated behavioral health treatment program designed to help those dealing with addiction build sober and healthy lifestyles.
Peer and community support for women living with HIV/AIDS. Outpatient Program information and meal on Nutrition Night, 6 p.m. Thurs. in Quest building or call intake coordinator.

Medications for alcohol, opioid/fentanyl, and methamphetamine use disorders. OHP and some private insurance companies accepted. Call for screening. Open Mon.-Fri MRT Groups on Zoom.

service_description: Intervention/prevention program for families with children 6 weeks to 5 years. listing: Wash. Co. Mental Health & Addiction Services
service_description: The Hawthorn Walk-in Center has resumed walk-in services during limited hours of Monday through Friday, 9 a.m.-2 p.m. Even during these times, individuals who need help are still encouraged to call the Washington County Crisis Line at 503-291-9111 before going to Hawthorn. The line is answered every day, 24 hours a day, by trained professionals who can help decide the best option for care. This may include providing assistance by phone, referring to other services, arranging a mobile team crisis response, or referring the person to Hawthorn. For referrals for treatment, education materials, presentations on addictions and information on treatment options in the county call member services line for Wash. Co. Health Share: 503-291-1155.
Food pick-up twice each month, all year. Includes health and hygiene items.

Individual, couples, family, and group counseling provided on a sliding scale of $0-$80. In-person and Telehealth sessions available, based on client preference. We work with children, adolescents, and adults. Client Request for Services forms are available on our website  or call 971-242-2826 to have forms mailed to you. We may have a waitlist for services and do not offer medication or crisis counseling.
